docs.lead_paragraph: This year, everybody vowed, would be different. The school superintendent, Michael Yazurlo, set aside two hours on consecutive Saturdays and opened his office door to hear the gripes. The Parent-Teacher Association, at the annual winter carnival in March, held a poster contest to promote interest in the election. When negative letters showed up in the weekly newspaper criticizing the district for ''excessive and irresponsible spending,'' dissenters fired back replies.

headline.main: School Budgets: Many Reasons Why Voters May Say No

docs.abstract: Article examines recent school budget voting in New York and delves into reasons why voters in Tuckahoe rejected budget proposal even though 92 percent of budgets passed statewide; some were opposed to increase in property taxes to support what they saw as overspending and lax controls; district can submit budget to voters again, with defeat bringing state-mandated austerity budget; map; photo (M)
docs.snippet: This year, everybody vowed, would be different.    The school superintendent, Michael Yazurlo, set aside two hours on consecutive Saturdays and opened his office door to hear the gripes. The Parent-Teacher Association, at the annual winter carnival...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sweaty and covered with cement dust, Volker Stasiak labored to pick up his speed at laying bricks. ''I have been in this business for 23 years, but this is entirely new for me,'' he said as he spread cement over another layer of bricks. ''The bricks are different. The tools are different. The whole system is different.''

headline.main: German Surprise! Who Are the Guest Workers?

docs.abstract: Eastern German town of Saxony, where 20 percent of work force is unemployed, is source of labor for other European countries--such as Britain, Ireland and Netherlands--where labor markets are tight; unemployed residents of Saxony are becoming 'guest workers,' reversing trend in which millions of foreigners were drawn to Germany for decades by promise of highly paid jobs but who had almost no prospect of citizenship; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A RIVER of clear plastic, destined to become supermarket produce bags, rushes past as Rafael Alvarado yells greetings in Spanish to workers on a noisy assembly line. ''Most of them are first-generation immigrants,'' said Mr. Alvarado, president and chief executive of Better Bags Inc. here. An immigrant himself -- he was born in Nicaragua -- he knows what it is like to come to a new country in search of a better life. Still, he said, ''no one is here as a favor; we all have to prove our value to the company every day.''

headline.main: Business; A Better Mousetrap? For This Immigrant, It's a Plastic Bag

docs.abstract: Better Bags Inc president, Rafael Alvarado, himself an immigrant, employs mostly first-generation immigrants to manufacture plastic bags for vegetables and fruit, for which he invented dispenser; company cannot compete with familiar rolls of plastic bags and therefore focuses on value-added features like thicker plastic, ease of use, less waste and six-color printing capability; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: GO back through all the writings on capitalism, back to Adam Smith, and a bedrock principle asserts itself repeatedly. It is that government provides services the private sector cannot provide as well or will not provide at all. Building airports and putting satellites into space are obvious examples. So is financing unemployment insurance. Yet in the current debate over tax cuts versus budget spending, this principle is ignored. The nation, as a result, is being locked into a $1.35 trillion tax cut over the next decade without ever hearing a discussion in Congress of how the government might have spent that money if there were no tax cut. Context is lacking. There is much debate over keeping the tax cut small enough to preserve the budget surplus or big enough initially to stimulate a weak economy. But no one insists on considering the many ways that government spending might be better than a tax cut in bringing Americans greater well-being in the decade ahead.

headline.main: Alternative To a Tax Cut: A Revitalized Public Sector

docs.abstract: Louis Uchitelle Economic View column on revitalized public sector as an overlooked alternative to enormous federal tax cut currently being formulated; says government spending might be more effective than cutting taxes in bringing Americans greater well-being in decades ahead; chart (M)
docs.snippet: GO back through all the writings on capitalism, back to Adam Smith, and a bedrock principle asserts itself repeatedly. It is that government provides services the private sector cannot provide as well or will not provide at all. Building airports and...

docs.lead_paragraph: China dismissed questions about its harsh controls over union organizing this week as it agreed to an ambitious program of cooperation with an international labor agency intended to improve the welfare of the country's huge and troubled work force. Under the new agreement, the International Labor Office, a United Nations agency charged with promoting worker rights and well-being, will become engaged in some of China's most explosive social issues, related to the growing turmoil in the work force. Illegal strikes and protests have become common as the country moves from a state-controlled economy, which promised workers cradle-to-grave security, to a market-driven system that has thrown tens of millions out of their jobs and left many others toiling in arduous or unsafe conditions.

headline.main: China Accepts U.N. Advice To Help Ease Labor Strife

docs.abstract: China signs accord with United Nation's International Labor Office for program to improve welfare of its huge and troubled work force; ILO will step up exchanges and advice on job creation, social security, workplace safety and such sensitive topics as collective bargaining and settlement of labor disputes; China seems determined to bar any probing of its ban on labor organizing outside Communist Party-sponsored trade union; Min Zhang Zuoji rejects ILO head Juan Somavia's stand that restrictive union rules violate basic principles of free association; Somavia asks China to free 24 prisoners jailed for labor organizing (M)
docs.snippet: China dismissed questions about its harsh controls over union organizing this week as it agreed to an ambitious program of cooperation with an international labor agency intended to improve the welfare of the country's huge and troubled work force.  ...

docs.lead_paragraph: PRESCRIPTION medicines are among the few consumer products that Americans feel they deserve the best of, yet don't want to pay for. A recent study by the National Institute for Health Care Management Research and Educational Foundation shows that spending on prescription drugs in the United States increased last year by 18.8 percent, to $131.9 billion. And there is little sign of a slowdown ahead.
docs.abstract: Health insurers are starting to require them to pay percentage of their drug costs, not just small co-payment; they and some policy makers are furious that drug companies pass their research development and advertising costs to consumers in US, while giving rest of world a subsidized price breaks; say that since consumers with drug plans are shielded from full cost of drugs, harshest impact if felt by nation's elderly, who lack prescription benefits, and those with most severe illnesses; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In this town of neon rainbows, where money gushes, time stands still and dreams endure despite the obvious odds, it is easy enough to think of Nevada as an adult version of Oz, and Las Vegas as its glittering Emerald City. But statistical realities in the nation's fastest-growing state are sepia-toned and stark. Pick almost any index of social well-being, and Nevada ranks at or near the very bottom of the 50 states, though it ranks near the top in personal wealth. Besides having the highest suicide rate (almost twice the national average), Nevada has the highest adult smoking rate and the highest death rate from smoking, the highest percentage of teenagers who are high-school dropouts, the highest teenage pregnancy rate and the highest rate of firearm deaths.

docs.lead_paragraph: For most of the last three years, the dozens of temporary-employment agencies in this city have had a problem. They could not find enough qualified workers for the openings that local companies needed to fill. Renate Hartman, who runs a branch of Snelling Personnel Services, noticed last year that many of the available candidates did not dress up for job interviews. Lee Rachelson, the founder of a small staffing company, said she had to post job listings on the Internet so she could recruit people from other cities to move to Tampa.

headline.main: Temporary Jobs Have Become the Victims of a Slow Market

docs.abstract: Article reports situation regarding temporary employment in Tampa, Fla; recently, job openings exceeded applicants; now, applicants outnumber jobs, which have fallen 20 percent or more; result is scarce jobs and lower pay for those in most need (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of the AremisSoft Corporation skidded yesterday after the company's stock began trading for the first time following articles critical of it in TheStreet.com and The New York Times. AremisSoft fell $1.30, or 9.8 percent, to close at $11.98, on volume of more than 9.5 million shares. For the week, the company's shares dropped more than 36 percent.

headline.main: Shares of Software Company Slide After Trading Resumes

docs.abstract: Shares of AremisSoft Corp fall 9.8 percent in wake of articles in TheStreet.com and New York Times questioning whether software company misled investors about value of its contract to modernize Bulgaria's health care information system (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Wall Street developed a sudden interest in Bulgaria this week, as investors scrambled to get the facts about AremisSoft, an obscure software company with a supposedly rich contract to overhaul Bulgaria's health information network. AremisSoft officials maintain the Bulgarian deal is worth $37.5 million. Last year, the company booked $7 million in sales under the contract, accounting for more than 5 percent of its total revenue.

headline.main: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall Street's New Interest In Bulgaria

docs.abstract: Investors scramble to get facts about AremisSoft, New Jersey-based software company that reported in December 1999 that it had contract worth $37.5 million to overhaul Bulgaria's health information network; documents filed by company with Securities and Exchange Commission in March 2000 indicate value of contract is less than $4 million; discrepancy is just one of problems weighing on shares of AremisSoft, which have fallen more than one-quarter in extremely heavy trading since May 14; graph (M)
